trans-unit.source: When <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> creates new files, the visibility of the new file (that is, which users can access it) is normally determined by the JVM environment and the file location only (that is, by the umask setting on UNIX and Linux systems and by the default file permissions on Windows NTFS).

seg-source.mrk: When <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> creates new files, the visibility of the new file (that is, which users can access it) is normally determined by the JVM environment and the file location only (that is, by the umask setting on UNIX and Linux systems and by the default file permissions on Windows NTFS).

target.mrk: When <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> creates new files, the visibility of the new file (that is, which users can access it) is normally determined by the JVM environment and the file location only (that is, by the umask setting on UNIX and Linux systems and by the default file permissions on Windows NTFS).

trans-unit.source: specifying permissions with Java SE 7 and up

trans-unit.source: file, specifying with Java SE 7 and up

seg-source.mrk: file, specifying with Java SE 7 and up

target.mrk: file, specifying with Java SE 7 and up

trans-unit.source: On Java SE 7 or later, <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> may further restrict the file permissions to the operating system account that started the Java process (that is, to the minimum access needed for operation). This means that other operating system accounts will have no access to directories or files created by <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>. This behavior can be helpful in enhancing default security for database files.

seg-source.mrk: On Java SE 7 or later, <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> may further restrict the file permissions to the operating system account that started the Java process (that is, to the minimum access needed for operation).
This means that other operating system accounts will have no access to directories or files created by <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>.
This behavior can be helpful in enhancing default security for database files.

target.mrk: On Java SE 7 or later, <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> may further restrict the file permissions to the operating system account that started the Java process (that is, to the minimum access needed for operation).
This means that other operating system accounts will have no access to directories or files created by <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>.
This behavior can be helpful in enhancing default security for database files.

trans-unit.source: The exact behavior is determined by two factors: how the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> engine is started, and the presence or absence and specified value of the property <codeph>derby.storage.useDefaultFilePermissions</codeph>.

seg-source.mrk: The exact behavior is determined by two factors: how the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> engine is started, and the presence or absence and specified value of the property <codeph>derby.storage.useDefaultFilePermissions</codeph>.

target.mrk: The exact behavior is determined by two factors: how the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> engine is started, and the presence or absence and specified value of the property <codeph>derby.storage.useDefaultFilePermissions</codeph>.

trans-unit.source: The two tables that follow show how file access works with Java SE 6 and with Java SE 7 and later JVMs. In both tables,

seg-source.mrk: The two tables that follow show how file access works with Java SE 6 and with Java SE 7 and later JVMs.

target.mrk: The two tables that follow show how file access works with Java SE 6 and with Java SE 7 and later JVMs.

trans-unit.source: "Environment" means that access is controlled entirely by the JVM environment and the file location only (that is, by the umask setting on UNIX and Linux systems and by the default file permissions on Windows NTFS).

seg-source.mrk: "Environment" means that access is controlled entirely by the JVM environment and the file location only (that is, by the umask setting on UNIX and Linux systems and by the default file permissions on Windows NTFS).

target.mrk: "Environment" means that access is controlled entirely by the JVM environment and the file location only (that is, by the umask setting on UNIX and Linux systems and by the default file permissions on Windows NTFS).

trans-unit.source: "Restricted" means that <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> restricts access to the operating system account that started the JVM.

seg-source.mrk: "Restricted" means that <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> restricts access to the operating system account that started the JVM.

target.mrk: "Restricted" means that <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> restricts access to the operating system account that started the JVM.
